title: Galena, Illinois
text:
Galena is the largest city in and the <a href="county%20seat">county seat</a> of <a href="Jo%20Daviess%20County%2C%20Illinois">Jo Daviess County</a>, <a href="Illinois">Illinois</a>, with a population of 3,429 at the <a href="2010%20United%20States%20Census">2010 census</a>. A section of the city is listed on the <a href="National%20Register%20of%20Historic%20Places">National Register of Historic Places</a> as the <a href="Galena%20Historic%20District">Galena Historic District</a>. The city is named for the mineral <a href="galena">galena</a>, which was in the ore that formed the basis for the region's early mining economy.
<a href="Native%20Americans%20in%20the%20United%20States">Native Americans</a>, primarily Mesquakie, Ho-Chunk, Sauk, and Menominee had mined galena in the area for more than a thousand years before European Americans settled in the area. Owing to these deposits, Galena was the site of the first major mineral rush in the United States. By 1828, the population was estimated at 10,000, rivaling the population of Chicago at the time. Galena developed as the largest <a href="steamboat">steamboat</a> hub on the <a href="Mississippi%20River">Mississippi River</a> north of <a href="St.%20Louis%2C%20Missouri">St. Louis, Missouri</a>. Galena was the home of <a href="Ulysses%20S.%20Grant">Ulysses S. Grant</a> and eight other <a href="American%20Civil%20War">Civil War</a> generals. Today, the city is a tourist destination known for its history, architecture, and resorts.
History.
Precolonial and colonial history.
The city is named for <a href="galena">galena</a>, the natural form of <a href="Lead%28II%29%20sulfide">lead sulfide</a> (PbS) and the most important <a href="lead">lead</a> <a href="ore">ore</a>. <a href="Native%20Americans%20in%20the%20United%20States">Native Americans</a> mined the ore for use in burial rituals. The <a href="Havana%20Hopewell%20culture">Havana Hopewell</a> first traded galena in the area during the <a href="Woodland%20period">Middle Woodland period</a> (c. 1–400 CE). However, the use of galena in the Havana territory is uncertain; very little has been identified in burial mounds. During the <a href="Mississippian%20culture">Mississippian period</a> (900–1500 CE), galena saw use as <a href="body%20paint">body paint</a>.
In 1658 <a href="French%20people">French</a> explorers, probably via contact with the <a href="Sioux">Sioux</a>, first noted lead deposits in the <a href="Upper%20Mississippi%20Valley">Upper Mississippi Valley</a>. A 1703 French map identified the northwestern Illinois area as "mines de plumb". Northwestern Illinois was inhabited by the <a href="Sac%20%28people%29">Sac</a> and <a href="Meskwaki">Fox</a> when the French arrived. In the 1690s, French <a href="Animal%20trapping">trappers</a> discovered the area and began mining the lead. However, conflicts with the Sioux prevented large-scale mining until <a href="Julien%20Dubuque%27s%20Mines">Julien Dubuque's Mines</a> opened across the river in 1788.
The French named the settlement as "La Pointe", and early American settlers adopted this name as "The Point" after the United States acquired the territory in the <a href="Louisiana%20Purchase">Louisiana Purchase</a> of 1803. Early documentation officially records the name as "Fever River", an early name for the <a href="Galena%20River%20%28Illinois%29">Galena River</a>.
This name did not appear to be widely used. <a href="George%20Davenport">George Davenport</a>, a retired <a href="Colonel%20%28United%20States%29">colonel</a> in the <a href="United%20States%20Army">United States Army</a>, successfully shipped Galena's first boatload of lead ore in 1816 down the Mississippi River. Three years later, Jesse W. Shull built a <a href="trading%20post">trading post</a>. The Thomas H. January family, who arrived in 1821 from <a href="Maysville%2C%20Kentucky">Maysville, Kentucky</a>, are considered the first permanent American settlers. The next year, the <a href="United%20States%20Department%20of%20War">US Department of War</a> assumed control of the mines and leased the lands out to operators. A large group of colonists led by Dr. Moses Meeker and James Harris arrived in 1823. Steamboat trade began in 1824.
American Boomtown.
The first official lease of the mines on behalf of the US government was dated September 30, 1822 and made to <a href="James%20Johnson%20%28Kentucky%20politician%29">James Johnson</a>, brother of <a href="United%20States%20Senate">US Senator</a> <a href="Richard%20Mentor%20Johnson">Richard Mentor Johnson</a>. Martin Thomas, appointed by the government in 1824 to oversee mine leases, was commissioned to survey the mines in 1826.
The name "Galena" was purportedly proposed during a town meeting that year; rejected names included Jackson, Harrison, and Jo Daviess. After Thomas platted the town, starting in June 1827, settlers could lease plots from the government. The land remained in government possession until the leasing system was eased out in 1836–37. When <a href="Jo%20Daviess%20County%2C%20Illinois">Jo Daviess County</a> was founded in 1827, Galena was named its county seat. This established the first courts in Galena; previous legal proceedings were heard in front of the Superintendent of Lead Mines. 21 million pounds of lead were mined in Galena from 1825 to 1828, and the population skyrocketed in that time from 200 to 10,000.
Local native tribes, then mostly Mesquakie and Ho-Chunk, permitted settlers to mine in established areas in Galena. However, the growth of the city led settlers to encroach on native land claims, as they sought new veins of lead. Following a murder of a pioneer family near <a href="Prairie%20du%20Chien%2C%20Wisconsin">Prairie du Chien, Wisconsin</a>, by the Winnebago, Galena closed its mines for safety and European-American residents prepared for war. They constructed forts at nearby <a href="Elizabeth%2C%20Illinois">Elizabeth</a> and <a href="Apple%20River%20Fort%20Site">Apple River</a>; although these were not used during the conflict, the forts provided residents with security and protection. The ensuing <a href="Winnebago%20War">Winnebago War</a> was little more than a skirmish, but as a result, the US annexed more lands near the city in the resulting 1829 <a href="Third%20Treaty%20of%20Prairie%20du%20Chien">Treaty of Prairie du Chien</a> which they forced on the Winnebago.
A meeting of townspeople on February 1, 1830, established the first fire department. At a town meeting at the county courthouse on September 7, 1835, sixty-five residents approved a motion for incorporation as a town. Eight days later, five individuals were elected as the first trustees. Incorporation was approved by the county board of trustees on October 2, and the first meeting of trustees occurred the next day. The 15th Illinois General Assembly (1836–37) codified the trustee election process. A steamboat was selected as the town seal on May 22, 1837.
A state law governing local jurisdictions resulted in the town holding its first elections for mayor and aldermen on May 24, 1841, to replace the board of trustees. Charles S. Hempstead was elected the first mayor, with 185 of the 356 votes cast. The first US census of the town was also held that year, recording 1,900 inhabitants.
<a href="Indigenous%20peoples%20of%20the%20Americas">Indigenous peoples of the Americas</a> traded galena with French traders as early as 1692. <a href="Julien%20Dubuque">Julien Dubuque</a> mined the ore in Iowa from 1788 until 1810. From 1807 until 1834, the United States government controlled leases, after which the lands were put up for sale. In 1839, <a href="David%20Dale%20Owen">David Dale Owen</a> made a geologic survey of the region. The <a href="Ordovician">Ordovician</a> <a href="Galena%20Group">Galena limestone</a> contained most of the galena ore, and peak productivity occurred between 1840 and 1850. By 1845 Galena was producing nearly 27,000 <a href="Short%20ton">tons</a> of lead ore annually, and Jo Daviess County was producing 80 percent of the lead in the United States. In 1852, the region produced 87 percent of the American output, and 10 percent of the world's.
Once one of the most important cities in the state, Galena was a hub on the <a href="Mississippi%20River">Mississippi River</a> between <a href="St.%20Louis%2C%20Missouri">St. Louis</a> and <a href="St.%20Paul%2C%20Minnesota">St. Paul</a>. Due to erosion, the <a href="Galena%20River%20%28Illinois%29">Galena River</a> is now inaccessible to steamboats. Galena received national attention in the 1860s as the home of Union General <a href="Ulysses%20S.%20Grant">Ulysses S. Grant</a>.
Decline.
Following a sharp decline in the demand for lead (which had been the city's chief income source during the early 19th century), Galena's population has dropped from 14,000 in the mid-19th century, to 3,396 in the early 21st century.
Today.
Galena's official <a href="flag">flag</a> was adopted in 1976 to symbolize <a href="mining">mining</a>, <a href="agriculture">agriculture</a>, <a href="steamboat">steamboat</a>s, and the nine <a href="American%20Civil%20War">American Civil War</a> <a href="general">general</a>s who lived in the city. Until the late 1980s, Galena was a small rural farming community.
In 1990, local industries included a <a href="Kraft%20Foods">Kraft Foods</a> cheese plant, Lemfco Foundry, John Westwick's foundry, and Microswitch, Inc. In the 1980s, Galena Mayor Frank Einsweiler initiated a tourist campaign. Since that time Galena's business district has emphasized its historic assets in the face of suburban development. Such long-standing businesses in the downtown area, including Stair's Grocery, Sullivan's Grocery, Clingman's Pharmacy, the oldest continuously operating pharmacy in Illinois, and <a href="Hartig%20Drug">Hartig Drug</a>, closed their downtown locations. Clingman's and Hartig's relocated to the outskirts of Galena, while Stair's and Sullivan's closed their doors permanently because of competition. In late 2010, Clingman's joined the Hartig's family and moved their pharmacy to Hartig's Drugs location along Highway 20.
The Country Fair in Grant Park has been an attraction that has helped increase tourist traffic to Galena as a destination. It is a craft show that attracts thousands of visitors to the area. The once boarded-up Main Street buildings have been renovated since the late 20th century. In 2010 Galena started a campaign called Vision2020, modeled after neighbor <a href="Dubuque%2C%20Iowa">Dubuque, Iowa</a>'s Vision 2010. A committee worked on outreach efforts with the community to form a vision of what residents wanted Galena to focus on for the next decade: five major concepts have been supported. In 2010, the 32nd annual Halloween Parade attendance was estimated at 15,000. In 2011, <a href="TripAdvisor">TripAdvisor</a> listed Galena among its top-ten "Charming Small Towns".
Geography.
Galena is located at (42.418171, −90.431472) along the <a href="Galena%20River%20%28Illinois%29">Galena River</a>, which is one of many tributaries of the <a href="Mississippi%20River">Mississippi River</a>.
According to the 2010 census, Galena has a total area of , of which (or 99.83%) is land and (or 0.17%) is water.
Galena is located in the <a href="Coulee%20Region">Driftless Zone</a>, an area that was not covered by <a href="glacier">glacier</a>s during the recent ice ages. This area, which includes the far northwestern corner of Illinois, escaped glaciation, while almost the entire state was glaciated, nearly to its southern tip. Because it escaped glaciation, this area is known for its hills, valleys, bluffs and considerable exposed rock.
Horseshoe Mound is a hill located outside Galena that U.S. 20 winds around before entering Galena. The view from Horseshoe Mound is one of the most photographed spots in the city. It stands at above sea level.
Climate.
Galena has a <a href="humid%20continental%20climate">humid continental climate</a> (<a href="K%C3%B6ppen%20climate%20classification">Köppen climate classification</a>: Dfa), with cold winters, hot summers, and four seasons. Annual precipitation is about 36 inches.
Because of the city's proximity to the Galena River, buildings have been threatened on numerous occasions by flooding. Eventually the Army Corps of Engineers built a dike to prevent city flooding. Galena's <a href="Congressman">Congressman</a>, <a href="Leo%20E.%20Allen">Leo E. Allen</a>, helped acquire funding for city <a href="floodgate">floodgate</a>s which were added in 1951 to connect to the river <a href="levee">levee</a> system. Significant recorded floods include:
Demographics.
As of the <a href="census">census</a> of 2010, there were 3,429 people, 1,632 households, and 896 families residing in the city. The <a href="population%20density">population density</a> was 819.4 people per square mile (358.2/km2). There were 1,960 housing units at an average density of 470.0 per square mile (188.5/km2). The racial makeup of the city was 93.6% <a href="White%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">White</a>, 0.5% <a href="African%20American%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">African American</a>, 0.7% <a href="Native%20American%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Native American</a>, 0.6% <a href="Asian%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Asian</a>, 3.7% from <a href="Race%20%28United%20States%20Census%29">other races</a>, and 1.0% from two or more races. <a href="Hispanic%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Hispanic</a> or <a href="Latino%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Latino</a> of any race were 8.3% of the population.
There were 1,632 households, out of which 20.8% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 42.0% were married couples living together, 8.7% had a female householder with no husband present, and 45.1% were non-families. 39.3% of all households were made up of individuals, and 19.9% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.05 and the average family size was 2.71. In the city, the population was spread out, with 19.5% under the age of 19, 4.2% from 20 to 24, 26.9% from 25 to 44, 29.5% from 45 to 64, and 24.1% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 44.7 years. For every 100 females, there were 93.9 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 88.8 males.
The median income for a household in the city was $45,409, and the median income for a family was $53,438. Males had a median income of $31,809 versus $30,000 for females. The <a href="per%20capita%20income">per capita income</a> for the city was $24,117. About 5.9% of families and 7.9% of the population were below the <a href="poverty%20line">poverty line</a>, including 13.8% of those under age 18 and 7.0% of those age 65 or over.
Culture.
Galena is the home to the Galena Art Center and the Galena Arts and Recreation Center. Turner Hall, a 19th-century building on Bench St., has been restored to serve as a performance venue and a popular wedding site. Galena is also home to several historic sites owned by the State of Illinois including the Old Market House, the Ulysses Grant Home, and the E.B. Washburn Home. The Galena/Jo Daviess County Historical Society also owns a number of historical sites including the Galena and U.S. Grant Museum and the Old Blacksmith Shop. They are building a new museum building at the site of the Stillman Mansion property.
Galena hosts dozens of major events a year, including the annual Halloween Parade which draws thousands of onlookers. 
Tourism.
Galena is a popular tourist destination hosting well over one million visitors each year. Galena is also popular with <a href="Chicagoan">Chicagoan</a>s, many of whom keep second homes in the area.
Cityscape.
85 percent of the structures in Galena are within the <a href="Galena%20Historic%20District">Galena Historic District</a>, which is listed on the <a href="National%20Register%20of%20Historic%20Places">National Register of Historic Places</a> and greatly contributes to the city's popularity. The <a href="Old%20Market%20House%20State%20Historic%20Site">Old Market House State Historic Site</a>, built in 1845, is a museum of local <a href="social%20history">social history</a>. Main Street was one of the first in the state to require architectural review of exterior building modifications. Zoning restrictions against wood-structure buildings contributed to the prevalence of brick buildings. All along Main Street the architectural style and historic feel create a unique atmosphere.
Efforts to improve the existing infrastructure while preserving the character of this neighborhood continued in 2003 with the adoption of a comprehensive plan. The plan outlines details on burying utilities, replacing parking with bike lanes and several beautification initiatives. This historic district has garnered the attention of dozens of volunteer groups who work to beautify and increase the utility of the area.
As the premier street in the second most popular tourist destination in Illinois those planning Main Street must be focused on balancing new developments along the waterway, and the transition to commercial stores with the charm provided by natural areas and long standing businesses. Trolley Cars follow parade routes north and south on Main Street and connect shopping to parks and wineries. The town is home to several wineries in the <a href="Upper%20Mississippi%20River%20Valley%20AVA">Upper Mississippi River Valley AVA</a>. In the area, there are 450 vineyards and 100 wineries available to visit. Main Street in downtown Galena has a large number of specialty shops, restaurants, a brewery, and multiple <a href="wineries">wineries</a>.
Galena's <a href="Saint%20Michael%27s%20Church%20%28Galena%29">Saint Michael's Church</a> was founded by the pioneer priest <a href="Samuel%20Mazzuchelli">Father Samuel Mazzuchelli</a>. The church is named after one of the three <a href="Archangel">Archangel</a>s. Opened in 1855, the downtown DeSoto House Hotel is the oldest operating hotel in Illinois. Rooms 209 and 211 of the hotel were used as Ulysses S Grant's campaign headquarters during his presidential campaign. Future president Abraham Lincoln gave a speech from the hotel's Main Street balcony on July 23, 1856, supporting John Fremont's bid for presidency. Two years later, on July 25, 1858, Senator <a href="Stephen%20Douglas">Stephen Douglas</a> spoke from the same balcony. Other famous guests include <a href="Theodore%20Roosevelt">Theodore Roosevelt</a>, <a href="Mark%20Twain">Mark Twain</a>, <a href="Susan%20B.%20Anthony">Susan B. Anthony</a>, <a href="Ralph%20Waldo%20Emerson">Ralph Waldo Emerson</a>, <a href="Horace%20Greeley">Horace Greeley</a>, <a href="Frances%20Willard">Frances Willard</a>, <a href="Elizabeth%20Cady%20Stanton">Elizabeth Cady Stanton</a>, <a href="Robert%20E.%20Lee">Robert E. Lee</a>, Chief <a href="Black%20Hawk%20%28Sauk%20leader%29">Black Hawk</a>, <a href="Millard%20Fillmore">Millard Fillmore</a>, and <a href="Zachary%20Taylor">Zachary Taylor</a>. General <a href="Winfield%20Scott%20Hancock">Winfield Scott Hancock</a> stayed in Room 223 for an extended period of time. There are also several <a href="resort">resort</a>s and <a href="golf%20course">golf course</a>s in the Galena area.
In celebration of the 2018 Illinois Bicentennial, Galena Main Street was selected as one of the Illinois 200 Great Places by the <a href="American%20Institute%20of%20Architects">American Institute of Architects</a> Illinois component (AIA Illinois) and was recognized by USA Today Travel magazine, as one of AIA Illinois' selections for Illinois 25 Must See Places.
Education.
Dr. John O. Hancock opened the first school in September 1826. The Galena Academy followed in 1832. Galena is home to <a href="Galena%20High%20School%20%28Illinois%29">Galena High School</a> and since 1992, Tri-State Christian School.
Notable people.
The nine generals.
Galena was the home to nine Civil War generals.<ref name="Dispatch/Argus-2011-12-23">
</ref> Foremost among these is Grant, who first came to Galena with his wife <a href="Julia%20Grant">Julia</a> in 1860 to work in the family tannery and leather-good shop. A veteran of the <a href="Mexican%E2%80%93American%20War">Mexican–American War</a>, Grant was called upon to train a regiment of volunteers raised in Galena when the <a href="American%20Civil%20War">Civil War</a> broke out in 1861. Through the support of local <a href="United%20States%20House%20of%20Representatives">congressman</a> <a href="Elihu%20B.%20Washburne">Elihu B. Washburne</a>, Grant became Galena's first general when promoted by <a href="Abraham%20Lincoln">Abraham Lincoln</a> on May 17, 1861. Washburne later served a brief stint as Grant's <a href="United%20States%20Secretary%20of%20State">Secretary of State</a> and then as <a href="United%20States%20Minister%20to%20France">Minister to France</a>. Victories at <a href="Battle%20of%20Missionary%20Ridge">Missionary Ridge</a> and <a href="Battle%20of%20Lookout%20Mountain">Lookout Mountain</a> prompted Lincoln to promote Grant to <a href="lieutenant%20general%20%28United%20States%29">lieutenant general</a> on March 3, 1864, giving him command of all <a href="Union%20Army">Union Armies</a>.
Grant returned victorious to Galena in 1865 and the citizens gave him an <a href="Italianate">Italianate</a> two-story brick house, today recognized as the <a href="Ulysses%20S.%20Grant%20Home">Ulysses S. Grant Home</a> State Historic Site. He was selected as the candidate of the <a href="Republican%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Republican Party</a> for the <a href="1868%20United%20States%20presidential%20election">1868 presidential election</a>. Grant was elected and served two four-year terms. He did not return to Galena. The Grants had four children: <a href="Frederick%20Dent%20Grant">Frederick</a>, <a href="Ulysses%20S.%20Grant%2C%20Jr.">Ulysses</a>, <a href="Ellen%20Wrenshall%20Grant">Ellen</a>, and <a href="Jesse%20Root%20Grant%20%28politician%29">Jesse</a>. Frederick became a major general and served as Minister to <a href="Austria-Hungary">Austria-Hungary</a>. Ulysses, Jr., built the <a href="U.S.%20Grant%20Hotel">U.S. Grant Hotel</a> in <a href="San%20Diego%2C%20California">San Diego, California</a>.
<a href="Augustus%20Louis%20Chetlain">Augustus Louis Chetlain</a>, who captained the regiment that Grant trained, was later <a href="brevet%20%28military%29">brevetted</a> to major general. Jeweler <a href="John%20E.%20Smith">John E. Smith</a>, who raised the <a href="45th%20Illinois%20Volunteer%20Infantry%20Regiment">45th Illinois Volunteer Infantry Regiment</a>, was also brevetted a major general. <a href="Ely%20S.%20Parker">Ely S. Parker</a> drafted the <a href="Battle%20of%20Appomattox%20Court%20House">Appomattox</a> surrender terms of the <a href="Confederate%20States%20of%20America">Confederacy</a> and was the only <a href="Native%20Americans%20in%20the%20United%20States">Native American</a> general of the Union. President Grant appointed him <a href="Commissioner%20of%20Indian%20Affairs">Commissioner of Indian Affairs</a> in 1869. <a href="John%20Aaron%20Rawlins">John Aaron Rawlins</a>, who served a term as city attorney in 1857, was brevetted in 1865 and briefly served as Grant's <a href="United%20States%20Secretary%20of%20War">Secretary of War</a>. Brevetted brigadier general <a href="John%20C.%20Smith%20%28politician%29">John C. Smith</a> later served as <a href="Illinois%20Treasurer">Illinois Treasurer</a>, <a href="Lieutenant%20Governor%20of%20Illinois">Lieutenant Governor</a>, and Grand Master of the state <a href="Freemasonry">Masonic order</a>. Gunsmith <a href="Jasper%20A.%20Maltby">Jasper A. Maltby</a> was promoted to brigadier general at the <a href="Siege%20of%20Vicksburg">Siege of Vicksburg</a>. John Duerr was brevetted in 1865, and later was a successful merchant in <a href="Monticello%2C%20Iowa">Monticello, Iowa</a>. <a href="William%20R.%20Rowley">William R. Rowley</a> was brevetted in 1865, and later became a county judge.
